Journal Story: Getting some help from my wife signing up for trailjournal.comÂ  Another checkmark in the process to being ready for the beginning of our March 16th thru-hike with my friend Jeff.

We've done a couple shake down backpacking trips to test our ultra light equipment.Â  One was early November and the temperatures were down to middle to low 20's, which we felt was a good test for gear performance in relationship to what we might encounter in GA starting out.Â  As we all know you can't trust the weather.Â  We were hiking in the high 20's and 30's in the day, and one day had snow squalls off and on.Â  We have got our pack weight down to about 22 lbs. and that includes 5 days of food, but not water.Â  We feel with odds and ends we will be a couple pounds heavier.

We've been planning this trip for close to 2 1/2 years over that time I have read approximately 25 books and reread some of them more than once.Â  All in search of information.Â  It's already been an interesting journey. We have certainly put in a termendous amount of work already, testing different foods when backpacking.Â  We also went to Warren Doyle's ATI 5 day class in TN in March of 2021, which was good for quite a few nuggets of information.Â  We got to see a few trails with three short hikes.Â  We feel we are just about ready to go now, a few more odds and ends, we'll be steppingon the trail in 78 days!

Been ramping up our hiking mileage since September and October, logging around 100 miles a month,Â  125 a month and November and December.Â  We are hopipng to push that to 200 miles a miles a month for January and February.Â  We feel that will get us in good condition for the start of the 2200 mile journey.Â  We plan on carrying equal to or more than our projected pack weight in January and February, and of course here in Massachusetts and the North East we will have plenty exposure to cold weather the next two months.

ordered a few final (I hope) odds an ends from ZPack yesterday, weathers been tough. Below zero wind chill on the 14th an 15th. Got out yesterday and a snowstorm to clean up today. Looking forward to putting some miles on tomorrow.

Cold weather is back, -3 this morning want to get out for some miles this afternoon, carrying almost my full pack weight on my hikes now. Hiked 10 miles Friday in freezing rain and sleet. Iâ€™m used to hiking in weather like that which hopefully will help in Georgia. Leave 5 weeks from tomorrow to drive to Springer Mountain, on the trail 2 days later. Iâ€™m ready mentally a few loose ends to finish up.

we got about 9 inches of snow Friday, nice powder easy to hike in. Got out for some good mileage Saturday and Sunday carrying just about my full anticipated weight. Pretty much ready to get on the trail. Â Headed out with the Mule tomorrow morning for some hiking locallySupposed to be single digits overnight.
nice morning hike today with Mule. Chilly start around 17 degrees but warmed up a little. Looking forward to getting down south.
last training hike.Thursday. Leave for Georgia tomorrow the14th, will be on the trail the 16th.

started our journey at Springer mountain on 3/16 at 9:25. Lite rain an mist all day . Hiked 8.1 miles and stayed at Hawk mountain shelter. Good first day meeting hikers. 3/17 left campsite at 8:20 intending to get to Woody Gap a 12.5 mile hike. Much harder than the first day sun came out around 10:40 and it got hot which us Northern boys werenâ€™t used to after hiking all winter in Massachusetts. Got thru the day . Set up camp a little after 4:00. Had 3 different people show up with trail magic( food and snacks) at different road crossings.

Got an early start, trying to beat the rain forecast for 11:00. Hard climb early but moved well hoping to get to Neels gap today. Cooler day a lot easier hiking than yesterdayâ€™s hot temperatures. Made our first 6 miles to Jarrod gap in 3.5 hours. As we approached Georgiaâ€™s highest peak we could here thunder starting! Hike up over Blood Mountain in a thunderstorm and pouring rain, came down the tough slippery decent. Lots of rock ledge ( slippery) but we were careful and got into Neels Gap outfitters where the AT literally goes right thru outfitters. Took a picture of the famous sneaker tree. These are hikers who quit the AT and throw there sneakers in tree. Got a room an shuttle into Blairsville. To dry out. Weâ€™re here with Willow, Ramblin man and Ranger Randy among others. Back to Neels gap in the morning.

Stayed in a motel in Blairsville last night to dry out and wash laundry. Sleeping in real bed was nice! We had breakfast with Willow ( a girl weâ€™ve met from Utah) then grabbed a shuttle to Neels gap. Rambling man and Ranger Randy beat us to trail and we ran into Justin an Nicole who camped past Neels gap. That group of people seem to be hiking at same pace as us we see them on the trail daily and end up in same campsites so weâ€™re making similar decisions. Rambling Man and Ranger Randy have both done thru hiked before so they have great knowledge.Weâ€™re trying to be smart about acclimating to trail, we trained a lot but when you do it every day we have to let our bodies get use to grinding out Mountains every day. We went over our 13th mountain in four days today. We went overLevelland mountain,Cowrock mountain,Wildcat mountain ouch! And finished with Poor mountain before ending in Low Gap Shelter. But the story of the day was the trail magic after descending from Wildcat mountain. A group of 8-10 people were set up at Road crossing. The menu homemade black bean soup, hard boiled eggs, peanut butter and jelly. Or homemade pound cake, homemade gluten-free brownies gator raid coffee soda sweets! Comfortable chairs to sit in. Took about a half hour break. Great people lots of fun. Extremely windy tonight, supposed to get cold in 30â€™s. Cold weather gear will earn its keep tonight.Not sure how far weâ€™ll go tomorrow. A couple different options it depends how weâ€™re feeling.

Sunday and Monday I had no internet reception. That will happen probably a lot, which means I canâ€™t post anything. Sunday we hiked our longest day yet13.6 miles. From Low Gap shelter to Cheese Factory tent site, pretty hot outside. Great views and continue to meet other hikers. A lot nicer camping then the winds that howled last nite. Had some coyotes running and howling thru the tent site at 3:00 in the morning just to let us know we were trespassing on their territory. My best nite sleeping. Monday we decided to hike to Deep gap shelter 9.4 miles to set up a resupply in Hiawassee on Tuesday. A little cooler we flew covering the distance in just over 5 hours.We went over Trey Mt.,young Lick Knob ( these knobs are mountains where I come from!) Sassafras and Kelly Knob. Got into camp about 1:45 which with warm temperatures made a beautiful day to kick back and get to know hikers as they slowly streamed in. Had a 2:00 AM visitor l swing at my tent! A mouse which I drove away but not deterred he came back at 3:00 and 4:30. Didnâ€™t get much sleep protecting my equipment! But no damage to tent. We headed to Dickâ€™s creek Gap this morning a quick 4 miles out. We hitched a ride from Ranger Randy whose brother in law pick him up and gave us a ride to our room at Holiday Inn.spent the afternoon walking around town to get our food resupply for 3-4 days. Taking our first zero day(0 milage) Wednesday Thunderstorms and 2-4 inches of rain expected. Great timing weâ€™ve been moving well but our legs can use 11/2 days rest. We did plenty of training but not7 days straight with full packs going up and down mountains. Care of our bodies early will pay dividends down the trail, many people try to pound out milage and end up with injuries. So far weâ€™re pretty good. So weâ€™ll watch the storm tomorrow and get back on it Thursday. We should complete our first state ( Georgia) and head into North Carolina by early afternoon.

taking it easy today. Weather was bad overnight but we needed a rest day. Leaving early (7:30) from lodging should be on trail before 8:00 Hope to be leaving our first state early afternoon and starting our 2nd state.North Carolina.

Iâ€™ve had no internet serviceÂ the 24 and the 25. We keep our phones on airplane mode while hiking to conserve the battery so often times we may briefly have service but donâ€™t know it. Iâ€™ve got Jean posting photos for me because sheâ€™s better at it. We left Dickâ€™s Creek Gap about 8:00 with Ranger Randy and Ramblin Man climbing right off. Came up a few small peaks Just before noon a nice milestone. We left Georgia and Entered our 2 nd state North Carolina! Stopped for lunch and then climbed Courthouse Bald Mountain at 4708 the after numerous ups an downs climbed to Muskrat Creek Shelter by 2:00. Mile and I decided to push on because we wanted to reach Franklin in 2 more days to resupply.we hiked another 4.9 miles to Standing Indian Shelter and slept at our highest elevation yet at 4742. Very cold nite I slept in the 3 sided shelter for the first time. March 25 Friday I was really beat when we got to shelter last nite, we had hiked 16.7 miles our longest day by 3 miles so far. But it set up a 700 vertical feet assent in the morning of Standing Indian Mountain at 5435, a lot easier since we started at 4700 feet . The views were spectacular. I felt good all day in spite of the long day before. Camp at Betty Creek Gap. Very cold and the wind howled all nite. I sleep with my ear plugs in, my cold weather gear is working fine, I was comfortable all nite. Got up in the dark a little after 6:00, my estimate is wind chill in the single digits. We left camp bundled up pretty good with all our cold weather gear on. In front of us at mile 2.5 was Albert Mountain at 5250 feet. As we climbed we shed clothes. A steep rocky ascent sometimes hand over hand. We made the top by 9:45 and another milestone the 100 mile mark. Great views but we didnâ€™t hang around too long the wind was howling and temperatures low. For every 1000 feet of elevation the temperature drops approximately 3.5 degrees.We weâ€™re trying to reach Winding Stair Gap 10 more miles away to get to Franklin on a resupply. Hiked hard all day had a challenging steep climb to about 4500 feet near the end of day and still made it to Winding Stair Gap just before 3:00. Got a shuttle for the 10 miles into town, checked into a motel, got dinner and hit the grocery store. Ran into Ranger Randy and Ramblin Man at the hotel. We have a shuttle coming at 8:30 to head back out tomorrow. So we can do it all over again. About 11.5 miles on tap tomorrow and numerous 5000 footers.ðŸ˜€

Power of example! While getting breakfast at motel,talked with a hiker hiking with his son. Heâ€™s Blind or almost . He uses a white stick walking around motel I saw him in Hiawassee and didnâ€™t talk to him, his son leads and warns of upâ€™s an downs he follows using trekking poles in place of his usual white stick. Wow !! Impressive! So we started at Winding Stair gapSt 9:00 by the time we got dropped by shuttle. Wind has been blowing for 3 days 30-40 mile per hour gusts. Started up right away on a Â 4.5 mile climb up Solar Bald Mountain 5001 feet. Good cardio! Went down to 4200 and back to 5200. It was cool so it helped.Finished by climbing Wayah Bald Mountain at 5342. Fantastic lookout with a tower, we could see a wildfire burning in the distance , panoramic view. Hiked about a mile down to Wayah Bald Shelter. Sleeping in a 3 sided shelter, windy and supposed to be in low to mid twenties. Changing our schedule . Planning on 16 miles tomorrow if weâ€™re feeling good to the Nantahala Outdoor Center. A quick stay over and 2 day resupply to Fontana dam. Trying to beat the weather,thunderstorms and heavy rain coming Thursday. So weâ€™re looking to do 44 miles in 3 days to miss the rain.

Tried to post earlier we have no power did a long post and it didnâ€™t come up so Iâ€™m reposting. Monday awoke at Wayah Bald Shelter to half frozen water bottle. I think it was in low twenties. Headed to the Nantahala outdoor center. Whitewater rafting,kayaking ect. They hosted the Olympic trails for whitewater kayaking there one year.went over 3 mountains, 2-5000 footers then had the Jump off decent a 900 foot decent in short distance I Â th drops hundreds of feet right beside our 18-24 inch trail.Our longest day yet 16.5 miles got to The Noc late in the day.

Stayed at the Noc had dinner with Ranger Randy, got an early start on Tuesday 3 mountains two Balds ( mountains here with fields on top) good day cool less wind.finished with a brutal climb 600 vertical feet in about 3 tenths of a mile. Great cardio! Â Then .9 to Brown Fork GapÂ Shelter. Stayed in the shelter We did 16 miles for the 2 nd day in a row. Plenty of stretching and care of body daily. Warm nite headed to Fontana Dam in the morning.

Got a start around 8:00 a little behind Ken Daddy Bug And Bug. Had Masters come up behind ( I gave him hikers name heâ€™s from Augusta Georgia) good hike over some peaks but hot using more water. When weâ€™re out backpacking itâ€™s a little different than going out for a walk or even a short hike with nothing on your back. Weâ€™re carrying between 25- low 30â€™slbs. Of weight depending on how many days of food we have. The trails are rocky full of roots and uneven, then you climb over roots and trees that have come down. So the way I look at it body preservation is my number one focus. So I /we have to constantly be looking down so we donâ€™t trip . What I try to do is always concentrate on landing my foot evenly not at angles to avoid foot and body stress , heel to toe this journey has just started and I want to concentrate on the body! We went over some early mountains then a long descent into Fontana Dam got there around 2:00 and a shuttle to lodge around 3:15. Checked in showered headed to laundry it had been 7 days . We were getting ripe. We have one pair pants one short sleeve and on long sleeve shirt and sleep clothes. So you hang out at laundry in you rain suit top an bottom! Had dinner Â and called it a nite.

Hiked from Fontana Marina today, April Fools Day!Â  Heading for the Smokies.Â  Started at mile 164.7.Â  Hiked past Fontana Hilton, a famous shelter near the dam.Â  Pictures will follow when I have better internet.Â  Got to Fontana Dam, WOW!Â  What a structure built as part of war effort during World War 2.Â  Then up into the Smokey Mountains.Â  Notorious for difficult weather.Â  Left out permits in the drop box and headed in.Â  Fontana Dam's elevation is 1700 feet, we we're headed up to 4700.Â  We were carrying our heaviest packs. Six days of food and some water, so we were about36 pounds hiking uphill for four hours.Â  We went over three mountains and got to Mollie Ridge Shelter around 3:00.Â  The weather was perfect for up here, sunny and in the 40's. So, we decided to hike on to the next shelter that was 3.1 more miles away.Â  We have pretty good weather forecasted for the first three days we are in the Smokies, so we need to get miles in to try to get in and out.Â  The AT in the Smokies is about 74 miles.Â  Sleeping in a three sided shelter tonight with a fireplace attached on one side.Â  The temperature is in the low 30's.Â  We will come close to the 200 mile mark and the highest mountain on the AT, Clingsman Dome at 6600 feet.Â  Should be there early Sunday!

We left Russel Field Shelter just after 8:00.Â  Climbed to 5400, over 1000 feet to Rocky Top mountain, then another 100 feet to the summit, Thunder Head Mountain.Â  We did 1000 foot descend and then climbed Derek's Knob at 4884.Â  Knobs are likeÂ  mountains back where I live!Â  Finally arrived at Silers Bald Shelter at about 5500 feet, where we are spending the night.Â  Saw some panoramic views today at some different lookout points. We had six deer grazing within 30 yards of the shelter with people around, but it didn't seem to faze them. We have had a couple reports of hikers seeing bear but we haven't seen any yet. Very poor cell service here.Â  It's about 5300 feet, cold in the 30's but no rain!Â  Tomorrow morningÂ  we will summit Clingsman Dome at 6650 feet.Â  The highest mountain on the trail.Â  Did 14 miles today, pretty tough.Â  Trying to get through Smokies before weather turns on Tuesday.Â  I think we'll hiking in rain on Tuesday but we'll be at lower elevations.

Left Silas Bald Shelter at 5452, at 9:00 got down to 30 overnight and the winds kicked up. Wind chill was probably low teens.as we headed for the ATâ€™s highest peak at 6658. Up, up, up right away. We had to go over Mt Buckley first at 6603. It turned out that that was the real work of the morning. After getting up Buckley it was a short easy Climb to Clingsman Dome. A few milestones that Jean will post some pictures we took. First the highest peak on the AT. 2nd highest is Mt Washington in NH.number 2 the 200 mile mark is right there. And lastly we now have less than 2000 miles to Mt Katahdin in Maine. Went up the tower there is actually a completely handicapped wheelchair access to the top of the tower and what a Panoramic View. We had a clear cold day so view was awesome. Jean will post that picture. Long rocky descent to New Found Gap US441. The route to Gatlinburg a real neat tourist town and busy. Thereâ€™s a large parking lot for tourists ( weâ€™re still in the Smokey Mountains) views weâ€™re entering our third state Tennessee and in the parking lot a 2020 thru hiker had a big bus mobile home he drove 5 hours from northeast NC. To set up in parking lot to do trail magic for the hikers. 2 hot dogs, a banana, orange, granola bar and some nachos we caught a ride into Gatlinburg to the Microhotel.Weâ€™re both a little beat up and taking a Zero on the 4th . Iâ€™m going to get a massage for a cranky calf muscle. Out tomorrow at 7:25, back into Smokies. Rain forecast.

Got a shuttle from Gatlinburg, a real tourist town at 7:25 and arrived at New Found Gap around 8:00.Â  We had a 1000 foot climb to the top of a 6000 foot mountainÂ  over a couple of miles.Â  We watered up at a shelter and climbed many peaks, as the wind picked up.Â  The forecast called for 35-45 mph winds, and rain starting at 12:00.Â  And it did, just like clockwork! We got out our rain gear and it poured till 2:00.Â  Rained all the way to the next shelter.Â  We arrived in time to get the last couple of spots in the shleter.Â  Got setÂ  up and ate early.Â  There were lots of hikers around. Will be an early turn in tonight, and its cooling down.

Left Peck corner shelter at 8:10.Â  An immediate steep climb up Mt. Sequoyah at 5945 feet, followed by a climb up Mt. Chapmen at 6215.Â  Then climbed Mt. Guyot at 6302, followed by a long descent down Cosby Knob Shelter at 4788.Â  Weather was beautiful! Tomorrow we hike out of the Smokies!Â  A major accomplishment and we got through with great weather.
We're out of the Smokies!Â  We are at Standing Bear Hostel.Â  Hope to hit Hot Springs on Sunday by noon! Need to watch some golf!

The sun was poking out by 8:00 as we headed out on our final day in the Smokies.Â  A long steep climb to start the day up Mt. Cammerer at 4948 feet, just so we wouldn't forget the WORK in the Smokies!Â  Then a long descent to Davenport Gap, The Great Smoky Mountains National Park northern Boundary.Â  This is where we dropped our permit and surprise our hiking friends from the North were waiting for us!Â  John and Janet Korhonen met us today. They had lunch and snacks for us, and other hikers too.Â  It was great to see people from home.Â  They were in Florida and made a special detour to see us and provide trail magic.Â  What super nice friends! After lunch we hiked to Standing Bear Farm and Hostel to spend the night and do a lite resupply to get us over the mountains and intoÂ  Hot Springs, NC.Â  Hopefully Sunday morning!Â  The weather is calling for a winter storm, up to six inches tomorrow so we'll try to find shelter early.

We left Standing Bear Hostel ( a really neat place, I slept in the tree house) . Some pictures will follow but Jean my picture poster is having phone problems! Our goal was to reach Hot Springs NC in 2 days and a wake up( hiking term for a morning arrival in town). A lot of hikers were taking a double Zero miles day, because 6 plus inches of snow and cold along with brutal winds. Us Massachusettsâ€™s boys wanted to press on along with plenty of other hikers. Left the hostel around 8:00 and immediately started climbing. Ran into Randy or his trail name Roller( he Carrieâ€™s a small roller to massage his legs and body) Zi ended up hiking with him for 2 days our pace was the same. Weather was nice! Whatâ€™s this bad weather predicted? Around noon it started cooling and then as We summited MaxÂ Patch Bald Mountain the snow was coming. By the time we got to shelter we had about an inch an Â a half and cold. Shelter was full so we set up tents. Snow over nite and got down to about 20. So we had a few inches on ground in the morning. We decided to make a try for Hot Springs 18 miles away with more weather predicted.Snow Squalls all day and at higher elevations they were blowing sideways. Got a few more inches of snow and got into Hot Springs at 5:00. We were lucky Randy had gotten the last room at a lodge and it had three beds so Mule and I shared it with him. Had a nice burger and nachos. Sunday we are staying at the Laughing Heart Hostel so we will resupply for 41/2 days then wash our clothes and take a Zero day Â and try to make Erwin, Tennessee in 5 days. Closing in on the 300 mile mark weâ€™re at 275 now should go over it in a couple of days. Till the next time I have internet receptionâ€¦..

Had a nice big breakfast in Hot Springs at the Rocky Mountain Dinner, waiting for Post Office to open. Jeff had a few things to mail back. Got on the trail around 9:15 once we got in the trail we had a very long and steep climb , including going past lovers leap. We climbed continuously for a couple of hours Hot Springs is only at 1326 elevation and we end up going to 3534 feet so plenty of climbing. Beautiful day in the 70â€™s. At one point we were on a dirt road and a guy came along in a truck, heâ€™d been camping all weekend turkey hunting. He was headed out of the woods. So he gave me some trail magic water and energy bars. We got to shelter around 3:30 and decided to pitch tents. Cell service is great here so able to post tonight.

This is from Tuesday the 12th: We tented at Spring Mountain Shelter last night.It started raining pretty hard overnight. In the morning it was raining steady, and we hiked in heavy rain all day.Climbed Camp Creek Bald followed byBig Firescald Bald and went over white cliffs .These are usually spectacular views,but we missed it with rain and swirling fog. the latter half of the day was on a very rocky traverse of multiple summits some hand over hand climbs and using great care getting thru it.15.9 miles later we arrived at Jerry Cabin Shelter as the rain was ending.I ended up in the 3 sided shelter. everyone was hanging out clothes to attempt to dry them.

When I got up my clothes hadn't dried even though it was windy, so hopefully my body heat would dry them. I did have dry socks available so even though my boots were soaked they felt good.Had a quick 700 foot climb to start our cardio early up to 4700 feet. Came down to Devil fork Gap NC212 and parked on the side of the road was a women set up with trail magic. Chairs to sit in ,the sun was out. Gatorade,chips,cheese crackers all kinds of goodies took close to a half hour break. What a lady ,she does this about 5 times a week. I needed the break we were facing one of the toughest climbs yetup to Lick Rock at 4500 feetarrived at hogback Ridge Shelter at 5:15 found a spot in the shelter a tough 15.5 miles today.
We are both a little beat from the last month decided to go to hostel and take a short day on Thursday the 14th.

After a little over a month on the trail, I came to understand that I didn't want to go 5 to 6 monthes not seeing my wife Jean who's been my life partner for almost 48 years. I miss her more than these mountains can fulfill me every day. While I'm a little beat up physically with various muscle strains ect. overall i'm doing fine for a young 67 year old, Ha Ha. this was a tough decison that came over about 10 days. So I havn't given up on my journey I'm justÂ  reevaluating how I get there. At the Natures Inn Hostel I ran into what's called section hikers that do sections that may take 2,3or even 4weeks at a time. So I'm working on a plan to do some sections in the north, hopefully in the next couple weeks once the body heals up. I've got a plan to keep moving forward. I flew back to Massachusetts and got home 2 hours ago. Thanks for all the support and well wishes from everyone.It was great to get home and see Jean and of course mans best friend my German Shepard Marco.
my miles have been incorrect so Iâ€™m doing a adjustment that hopefully gets it correct. My current mileage is 319.7

Iâ€™m flying into Asheville today to get back on trail where I got off 12 days ago. I had some medical issues to deal with at home. Doctor gave me the ok to get back to trail so Iâ€™ll be getting back on trail tomorrow. My niece Heather is picking me up at the airport and getting me to Natures Inn a hostel today, then Iâ€™m off in the morning.

Back on the trail after a couple of weeks home. Flew into North Carolina and my niece Heather drove 2 1/2 hours to pick me up and drop me off.Â  I stayed at the hostel in Tennessee where I picked up the trail where I had gotten off at Sam's Gap. IÂ decided to put in a big day to set up hike into Erwin, TN.Â  My choice was to stop at noon at Bald Mountain Shelter or push another 10 miles to No Business Knob Shelter.Â  If I stopped at Bald Mountain Shelter, I'd have 16.8Â  to Erwin, instead I hiked 6 miles in today. I went over BIg Bald yesterday, what a site!Â  A couple miles of open fields.Â  Got to the shelter 18.3 miles later from start.Â  Got up early this morning and hiked a leisurely 6 miles to Erwin Tennessee. The laurel is in bloom.Â  Almost 2 months ahead of Massachusetts.Â  Got to Uncle Johnny's hostel and did a resupply. ordered food from Dominoes and kicked back for a couple of hours. The temperature was about 75 and blue sky's. Finished the day by hiking to Curley Maple Gap Shelter.Â  At mile 348.5.Â  Shared some dinner with some trail friends.Â  My second day mileage since I couldn't post yesterday is 28.8

I left Curly Maple Gap Shelter this morning and hiked to Beauty Spot, another Bald Mountain, what a view! Then I had a tough climb up Unaka Mountain which had a beautiful dense spruce forest at 5180 feet.Â  It would have been a great spot to camp, but was too early in the day.Â  My goal was to get to Cherry Gap Shelter.Â  Got there around 3:00.Â  I still had a little gas in my tank and wanted to get closer to my goal forÂ  tomorrow,Â  Roan High Knob Shelter.Â  This is the highestÂ  elevation on the AT at 6186 feet,Â  I hikedÂ  4.4Â  more miles to a beautiful grassy campsite pitched with tents with Dioysus and Corporate (who is from Spencer MA). My total miles today 17.2.

Got an early start up Roan Mountain.Â  By the time we got to the base of the mountain it was hot. Better than the notoriuos cold weather Roan is known for.Â  From the base it is a five mile ascent to the top where the highest elevation shelter on the AT is at 6186 feet.Â  We got there at 3:00.Â  It's a neat old shelter with a door and windows because the weather is so fierce.Â  I decided it was too early to stop, and since I have a bunk at a hostel tomorrow that is 16.3 miles away I wanted to get closer.Â  I hiked to Stan Murray Shelter 5.1 miles away.Â  Nice, fairly easy descent off of Roan Mouintain.Â  It comes out onto Carver's Gap TN and the Nort Carolina border.Â  Crossed the highway and a puff trail magic just left beside trail bananas, apples, oranges, Oreo cookies(my favorite), cheddar cheese, soda, and candy. I definitely needed a calorie boost, which consisted of 2 bananas, ten Oreos, 3 pieces of cheddar cheese, and a coke to wash it down.Â  I sure was full. I grabbed a banana, more cookies, and candy bars for breakfast and I was on my way!!!Â  Right in front of meÂ  Round Bald Mountain at 5827.Â  Once I climbed that, Jane Bald at 5899.Â  Â Once those were out of the way a quick stop for water for the night from a spring and arrived an hour later at Stan Murray Shelter.Â  Cooked dinner and headed to bed around 8:40.Â  Met a retired teacher from Minnesota, hung my bear bag, and lights out!

Got a good start from Stan Murray Shelter.Â  really strong winds last night and we got a little mist so it was blowing toward the shelter.Â  Things were damp in the morning.Â  Thunderstorms predicted for early afternoon so I was hiking fast.Â  I had 11.2 miles to get to the bunk I reserved at Mountain Harbor Bed and Hostel.Â  This place is famous for the best breakfast on the Appalachian Trail. I had three mountains to get over, Big Yellow Mountain at 5260 feet, then Little Hump Mountain at 5459 and finally Hump Mountain at 5587.Â  The last two beautiful "Bald Mountains" as they call them here are almost completely treeless, just open fields for a mile or two.Â  Got over them and hit Doll Flats, North Carolina and Tennessee border again.Â  I'm still windingÂ  between the two states.Â  I made the hostel by 12:15Â  4 1/2Â  hours.Â  Â Forty-five minutes later the thunder started and the sky opened up.Â  I had my first shower in five days and washed all my clothes.Â  Resupplied for 3 1/2 days and have Damascus VA in my sights, 76 miles away.Â  Looking forward to breakfast in the morning.Â  I met Lego from Norfolk, Massachusetts.Â  He'll be turning 67 on the trail and he knew right where Phillipston was!
Destination: Mountain Harbor Bed & Breakfast/ Hikers Hostel

Journal Story: I had one of the best breakfasts ever at Mountain Harbor Bed and Breakfast & Hostel.Â  A nice hostel annually voted best breakfast on the trail.Â  Souffles, pastries,strudels, fruit, sausage and more.Â  Got a late start because of it.Â  Had my sights set on Moreland Gap Shelter 18.6 miles away.Â  Felt loaded down early from breakfast and four days of food to get to Damascus.Â  Plus, it was a hot day temperature in the 80's.Â  Went past Elk River.Â  Almost jumped in to cool off.Â  That day is coming soon!Â  All day a rolling trail up an down, got to the shelter at 6:00 pm.Â  Ten tents up an no one in sleeping in the shelter, so I was tired and set up in the shelter.Â  I had a nice conversation with AT hikers during dinner.Â  That's it for today.Â  There is some rain predicted for tomorrow.

I left Moreland Gap Shelter at 7:15 this morning.Â  Bounced up and down a few ridges and came upon a deer at 15 yards.Â  It just watched me, and never run.Â  Went past Laurel Falls, nice sitem.Â  Then I did a steep climb up Pond Flats Mountain where I saw my first rattlesnake.Â  It was around three feet long and rattling away.Â  It was a hard climg and the temperature was around 80.Â  Went by Watauga Lake where there was a beach.Â  Â I couldn't resist and I went for a swim.Â  It sure was refreshing! I went by Wilbur Dam and hiked until 7:50 pm.Â  Ran into a bunch of hikers camping, so I decided to join them.Â  I was runningÂ  out of daylight.Â  Ended up with a 23 mile day. My biggest day yet!

Had rain overnight and a little this morning.Â  I had an 8:00 start after the 23 miles yesterday.Â  It was misting with a slight breeze all morning which was refreshingÂ to hike in.Â  It kept the temperature down.Â  Today was a constant rolling up an down the ridge line.Â  Went by Vandeventer Shelter, Iron Mountain Shelter, and then passed by Nick Grindstaff Monument which is a grave.Â  Passed by Double Springs Shelter and got to Low Gap US421 and bingo!Â  Trail magic!Â  There was about a dozen hikers in easy chairs provided by a 2019 thru hiker.Â  All kinds of fresh fruit, snacks. cold cuts, and candy.Â  I ate plenty .Â  I had hiked 19 miles already.Â  Also, I was out of food for tomorrow for the final 13 miles into Damascus.Â  He told me to take what I needed.Â  Got back on the trail, hiked two more miles amd set up tents with another hiker.Â  21 miles for the day!

Got an early start today.Â  I was on the trail by 7:00 .Â  I had 13.2 miles into Damascusand wanted to run errands.Â  I've got a room booked at the Virginia Creeper Lodge for two nights.Â  Taking a zero day Friday and it is supposed to rain heavy so that's good.Â  I got into town at noon.Â  Went to a coffee shop and had fresh fruit, 2 cappuccinos, a quesadilla, and topped it off with an ice cream!Â  Got bak to the lodge, checked in, and headed to town to resupply.Â  I washed my clothes later.Â  It's been hot , they were fragrant!Â  Kicked back the rest of the day

Sunday, cold and rainy overnight.Â  Pinky and The Brain (a husband and wife team) were at the shelter and also at the lodge in Damascus that I stayed at. They're in their early thirties.Â  I headed out a little before them headed for Wise Shelter. Plenty of interesting things today.Â  Going through Grayson Highlands, home to herds of wild ponies and also longhorn steers.Â  CrossedÂ  Virginia 601 and did a steep climb through fields, came over the hill and there were two ponies and a foal.Â  I wished them a Happy Mother's Day and kept moving.Â  Had a tough climb to the top of Whitetop Mountain and then it rolled for quite a few miles.Â  Climbed Mt. Rodgers, Virginia's highest peak over 5729 and started seeing more ponies Patted a couple but was intent on next milestone and sure enough in the trail mile 500!Â  Pretty neat! Went through numerous fields, saw more ponies and the Longhorn steers,Â  Finished at Wise Shelter mile 504.1.Â  Pinky and The Brain showed up just befgore dark.Â  No cell service.Â  Monday, hiked thru The Scales, more ponies and cattle.Â  It was a hot day, probably atound 80. Had a couple of good climbs, including a big one at the end to seeÂ  Comers Creek Falls, then down to Dickey Gap.Â  Got a shuttle bus to the hostel. Ran into some trail magic before the shuttleÂ  arrived, so that's always good!Â  Finished at mile 520.1

Held off leaving the lodge early because it was raining.Â  Left at 8:30 and it was sprinkling.Â  As I worked my way up the trail it went from a sprinkle to pouring.Â  It poured all day.Â  I reached the Lost Mountain Shelter at about 4:30 mile 486.6.Â  16.3 miles, a real fool day considering the weather.Â  We ended up with 4 in the shelter.

nice weather today. I was going to reach today, to get to Chatfield Shelter. Partnership Shelter famous for being able to get pizza delivered to the shelter was 14 miles away. Pizza sounded good but I had a reservation tomorrow at the quarter way Hostel so it was 21 miles today or 22 tomorrow. It was a hot day and going up an over Glade mountain was tough. I arrived at Chatfield Shelter at 7:50 it was getting dark. A nice surprise I ran into MacGiver who I havenâ€™t seen in about 5 weeks. I met him early on he turned 67 on the trail March 8th, I turned 67 on March 23 so we had that connection.I got set up in shelter and went to bed at dark. No cell service of course!

I only had 15.7 ( thatâ€™s a change of thinking) miles to hostel. I left camp around 7:45 weather was great, I ran into a trail maintainer early on cutting a tree that fell across trail. I stopped an chatted for a bit. Trail was a rolling up an down. Walked thru some beautiful fields and came out in Atkins Va. by interstate 81. Stopped at a truck stop convenience store. I had 2 pieces of pizza a coke 2 ice creams and put a bag of chips an danish in my pack for later. Got rolling again . MacGiver had showed up but he wanted to sit down and eat in a restaurant.Miles rolled by and I met a woman having lunch on side of trail. A real nice lady from Indiana I believe. She said to me; are you RP ? I said yes how did she know? She said Iâ€™ve been following you on trail journals! Pretty cool. She said the Quarter way point of the AT was just ahead. Sure enough it was a couple hundred yards. Nice milestone, got to Va610 and hiked to the hostel. What a great place, we had a great group there (5) for the night Â lots of lively talk, Tina the owner thru hiked in 2009 . She made a wonderful homemade breakfast in the morning the rest of them moved on. I was waiting for a shuttle, I had to go home to take care of some things and was flying out of Roanoke early Friday. Iâ€™ve got some things to attend to this summer so Iâ€™m hoping to do whatâ€™s know as a flip flop. Finish the north while the weather is decent then finish the south. Iâ€™ll be starting on the PA.and NJ border May 31 and heading North. So 1 day at a time the journey keeps moving. Craig T

heading North from Delaware Water Gap tomorrow. Skipping part of south for now to work on the Northern part of trail. Many thanks to Wayne Richardson and Chris Casella for driving me 51/2 hours here from home. Staying in town tonight, out in the morning.

I ran intoÂ  Ranger Randy my first day on the trail.Â  Definitely the highlight of my day. Haven't seen him since the Smokey Mountains.Â  I knew he had his daughter's college graduation that he had to get off the trail for and I knew he was planning on starting in New York and hiking south to where he got off the trail.Â  Mental telepathy, I was thinking of texting him 15 minutesÂ  before I ran into him ont he trail.Â  We hugged and had a nice chat.Â  He suggested I stay at the Mohican Outdoor Center, an AMC run hostel.Â  Almos 13 miles from my my start point.Â  It made snese for my first day back.Â  I hiked a rocky trail all morning, ran into around a hundred freshman students out with some leaders on a backpacking trip to transition them from freshamn year to sophmore year.Â  Pretty cool, then about a dozen outward bound kids from Philadelphia, all headed south.Â  I got to theÂ  Mohican Center around 2:00 in a cabin with 1 thru hiker besides myself and 3 section hikers.Â  Rain is predicted for the next three days.Â  One shelter closed ahead because of bear activitiy and IÂ  encountered a 2 foot rattlesnake that didn't want to give up the trail.Â  I got him to move along with my trekking pole. So, pretty nice day overall.

Left early at 6:15, was hoping for a 21 mile day. It was lightly raining but the humidity was really high. I got up the first climb and there was a slight breeze that helped a little.Â  Tough hiking, rocks everywhere! I went past Rattlesnake Swamp, got water from Rattlesnake Spring, and climbed Rattlesnake Mountain.Â  But, no rattlesnakes and I was good with that!Â  A little slow going between the humidity and rocks.Â  When I got to Brink Shelter around 2:00 it was closed because of problems with an aggressive bear.Â  At this point I knew I didn't want to go to the next shelter.Â  US 206 was 3.5 miles ahead and I was trying to beat a thunderstorm, which I did!Â  IÂ  caught up with Justin from New Mexico and we got a room. And then there was trail magic! A couple pulled over and gave us a 20 minute ride to a motel and then they said they would pick us up in the morning and bring us back to the trail. Wow! What nice people.Â  I saw one deer and that was it for wildlife.

Saturay morning it was pouring at 6:15. Our trail magic was supposed to pick us up at 7:00 to bring us back to the trail.Â  I called and we put it off until 9:00.Â  She showed up at 9:00 withÂ  banana and blueberry muffins.Â  She drove us to the trail head and we started a big climbÂ  for New Jersey.Â  It was very humid out. I'm still hiking with Justin from Albuquerque.Â  We made great time in spite of the New Jersey rocks. We were about an hour in whenÂ  it started to rain heavy. An hour later,Â  thunderstorms rolled in and we got pounded for aboutÂ  two hours with thunderstorms.Â  The pouring rain kept up too! A little over 12 miles , the rain stopped and started, but late in the day the sun finally came out. We set up in Rutherford Shelter.Â  We will be out early to battle the famous "New Jersey Rocks".

I shoved off at 6:45 this morning and labored over the last five miles of New Jersey rocks.Â  I took a wrong turn that cost me 20 minutes.Â  It was a beautiful hiking day after getting soaked yesterday.Â  Finally seeing some New Jersey views after two days of rain.Â  The winner today was taking a detour off the trail to hike into Unionville, New York to go to Horler's General Store.Â  It was aboutÂ  3/4 of a mile but well worth .Â  I got a nice deli pastrami sandwich on rye, a bag of chips, a coke, and sat on their porch and watched the world go by.Â  Then, I topped off my visit with two ice cream sandwiches.Â  I also did a two day resupplyÂ  there.Â  It was definitely a nice break on a hot day. I finished hiking to Pochuck Mountain Shelter.Â  A 17.2 mile day!Â  I saw deer, a small garter snake, duck, and Canadian geese.

Hot weather predicted, left shelter at 6:05 for an early start.Â  Hiked about 5 miles to the famous New Jersey Boardwalk.Â  It goes across a massive marsh almost 3/4 of a mile.Â  I transitioned to walking on boards, 2 wide for anothe .3.Â  Then, had the stairway to heaven climb up a mountain with fantastic views, lots of people hiking on a Monday holiday.Â  Saw a sow and two cubs, then aÂ  4 foot black snake.Â  Hiked along and came upon a bear 15 yards off the trail.Â  I could hear him chewingÂ  and breakingÂ  nuts.Â  Finally got to NJ/NY border and was in for the toughestÂ  hiking I've had yet climbing rock ledges hand over handÂ  for 4 miles.Â  Got toÂ  trail head at 7:30, totally beat!Â  Had called a motel and they shuttled me there and got my clothes washed for the first time in 5 days.Â  Saw 4 bear, 1 deer, 1 hawk at 20 feet, and 1 big black snake!
I got back on the trail at 10:00 after a nice stay at a motel.Â  Had a hot day hiking in the nineties.Â  Saw 2 deer, 3 snakes, and got to the shelter just before dark.Â  Thunderstorms over night.

We had some rain and thunderstorms roll in last night which cooled things off nicely.Â  Got on the trail by 7:00 .Â  It was nice and cool, finally good hiking weather.Â  I was moving along but had tired legs from the last two scorching days.Â  I made a decision to cut my miles today to 16 and try to get a room at the state park, Bear Mountain Inn, about 16 miles away.Â  Still lots of tough hiking.Â  I saw 3 deer. one which was really close.Â  The ATÂ  had a detour around Palisades Parkway.Â  I got on it and got lost.Â  It cost me about an hour and a half and about 2 miles.Â  So much for a short day!Â  Ha Ha!Â  Got on track and climbed Bear Mountain. Easy trip to the bottom.Â  The state has nice hiking paths for the public.Â  I just missed theÂ  rain.

Got out of Bear Mountain Inn at 7:00 and bumped into a solo hiker from South Carolina that I met a couple of days ago.Â  He is hiking to Great Barrington, Ma so we may hike together. It was a very, very, muggy day which translates to dripping with sweat! We are trying to get to the State Park tent site a little over 16 miles.Â  At 10:45 we came down to a major road.Â  There was a deli/convenience store.Â  I ordered a grinder, bag of chips, and a Coke.Â  Of course I topped it off with a Haagen-Daz ice cream bar.Â  This fueled me for the afternoon.Â  I saw Tee, Chatterbox, and other hikers there too.Â  Rain was predicted and it started pouring around 3:00.Â  We got soaked but I didn't mind.Â  It was like having a shower, and it kept away the mosquitoes that were having us for lunch!Â  We got to the State Park around 4:00.Â  Decided not to push for the shelter another 5 miles away, andÂ  set up our tents. There was eight of usÂ  here and Solo found a pizza house that would deliver so I didn't have to get into my food bag much today.Â  There is a shelter 19 miles away.Â  We will see if we can make that tomorrow.Â  No wildlife today!

We left Clarence Fahnestock State Park after more rain over night.Â  Headed for the Morgan Stewart ShelterÂ  20 miles away.Â  Light rain predicted for the morning after we got drenched yesterday.Â  By 8:00 it was raining like crazy, and we got soaked again for a couple of hours. Then the mosquitoes came out.Â  We put on some bug spray which helped. The trails were a little easier today.Â  About 3:00 we hit a road crossing and heard about a pizza place 3 miles away.Â  It was worth the walk and we got a ride to the trailhead.Â  The last five miles were long but we got to the shelter around 7:00

We left the shelter around 6:45 and headed for Wiley Shelter which is 16.8 miles away.Â  Nice hiking terrain, it reminded me of Massachusetts.Â  Some long 1/2 mile boardwalks over swampy areas.Â  I met some older hikers today. One was in his 80's, another 77.Â  Great to see! Only saw one garter snake today.Â  No wildlife.Â  Found a food truck parked close to a road crossing.Â  We had lunch and booked a room in Kent, Connecticut for tomorrow to wash clothes, resupply, and clean up.Â  A quick overnight than right out.Â  We'll be leaving NY some time in the morning.Â  We got to our shelter around 5:00.

Left the shelter by 6:00 AM.Â  13 miles into Kent CT.Â  We were hoping to cruise in there.Â  The trail was in and out of the NY/CT border.Â  The New York section was real tough, lots of rocks.Â  It took longer getting into town.Â  The owner of the inn that we were staying at picked us up at the trailhead.Â  We cleaned up and had lunch, then we headed to the laundry mat, and grocery store.Â  Did some grocery shopping while our clothes were washing. Got a resupply of food,Â  went back to the room and repacked our packs and went for dinner. The owner said she'll bring us to the trailhead at 7:30 AM.Â  We left NY today and entered Connecticut.Â  My 7th state!Â  Georgia, North Carolina, Tennessee, New Jersey, and New York complete. Virginia and Connecticut started.

We left Kent CT. at 7:30 this morning. Had a steep uphill immediately and soon went over Caleb's Peak. Then it was a steep, steep descend, down to the Housatonic River.Â  Followed a trail for around 5 miles right beside the river.Â  Very pretty!Â  The story of the day was the gypsy caterpillars. We saw a little bit in NY but today was TOTAL DEVASTATION! It was raining caterpillar poop!Â  I would run into caterpillars hanging by their silk.Â  It would stick to our shirts.Â  The trees were almost totally defolilated. So, because of that, no mast of leaves to protect us from the sun.Â  Late in the day, 3 huge climbs and we were happy to get at our shelter at 5:40.Â  No deer around the last few days.Â  I suspect the fawns are being born right now.

Left Pine Swamp Shelter at 6:30 with Solo.Â  It was fast hiking! We immediately climbed Sharron Mountain, hiking up and down rolling terrain.Â  We still had the gypsy caterpillars but not as bad.Â  GotÂ  to Falls Village CT fast so we hiked into town for lunch. Who do we see?Â  Mud Dog, Straps, Chatterbox, and Tee were eating there also. Nice to see familiar faces.Â  Had a nice lunch and then headed back to the trail.Â  Went past the Housatonic River Falls, then climbed Mount Prospect.Â  Finished with Lions Head Mountain and arrived at Brassie Brook Shelter around 6:10.Â  I stayed there with Mud Dog and Solo.Â  My friend Thom is dropping off my lighter pack and a four day resupply in Great Barrington tomorrow.Â  Still no wildlife for a few days.

We got a lot of rain overnight.Â  Had 17 miles to meet my friend Thom who was bringing my much lighter ZPack pack and a four day resupply.Â  I went through my pack and got rid ofÂ  2 1/2 lbs. of stuff I won't need for theÂ  7 more days I hope to be out here on this section.Â  For a total of about a 6 lbs. saving, which is huge,Â  Â Left the shelter at 6 AM with Solo.Â  Mud Dog stayed behind.Â  We immediately had Bear Mountain to climb.Â  It was very rocky and slippery.Â  The descent was dangerous for sure!Â  By 7:30Â  I was leaving Connecticut behind and entering Massachusetts, my 8th state.Â  We climbed Mt. Race.Â  Spectacular views at the top but again, difficult going down.Then we climbed Mt Everett, followed bt Mt. Bushnell and certainly the toughest descent of the day. It was slippery rocks all the way down! When we finally got down, it was pretty much smooth sailing to meet my friend Thom at Rt. 7.Â  Decided to grab a room with Solo.Â  We were beat!Â  Washed our clothes and I am getting ready for a big push to Vermont in about four days. Saw one porcupine on the trail today, as it scampered up a tree.

I delayed my shuttle this morning from the Quality Inn because it was pouring out.Â  I am so happy I grabbed a room last night. Got picked up at 9:00Â  and was on the trail at 9:10.Â  The trails were like rivers from all the rain. My feet were soaked soon.Â  It was a nice day of hiking though.Â  The wind was blowing, it looked like it wanted to rain some more but never did.Â  Went up June Mountain. then East Mountain.Â  Then hit Beartown State Forest.Â  A while after that I had the wildlife siting of the week.Â  Was just getting to a small hill and 15 yards in front of meÂ  crossed a Bobcat! He never saw me and didn't know I was there.Â  I got to Mt Wilcox North Shelter at 5:00 and Mud DogÂ  was there.Â  One other hiker came in later.Â  The weather looks good for the next few days.Â  Hoping to summit Greylock on Sunday!

I'm hoping for a big day today!Â  Shooting for October Mountain Shelter 23 miles away.Â  Got a nice early start, on the trail by 6 AM. There was a lot of up and down terrainÂ  early up Bald Mountain.Â  Went over the Mass turnpike and across Rt. 20.Â  Climbed Becket Mountain, Wailing Mountain, and finally arrived at the shelter at 6:15.

I slept an extra half hour after 23 miles yesterday and I am trying to follow it up with 21 today.Â  Hoping to get to Cheshire, MA. Left October Mountain Shelter at 7:00 .Â  By 8:05 I was at the famous cookie lady's place.Â  Her son brought me out two very nice chocolate chip cookies and I was on my way! The trail was friendly and I made good time.Â  I hiked into Dalton, the home of the Crane company who makes the paper our US dollars are printed on.Â  Very pretty, 'Beaver Cleaver' like!If you remember that show!Â  One man offered me water, then I stopped at Cumberland Farms.Â  Got two bananas, two ice creams and I hit the sub shop for a grinder. I was walking slower from all the food. I got rolling and made great time heading into Cheshire.Â  I booked a room and asked my wife Jean to come out for a visit, and she did.Â  We are at the Harbor House B&B. I'll get a later start tomorrow but it will be a great recharge.Â  I should be summiting Mt. Greylock somewhere around 3:00 hopefully then closing in on the Vermont border.
Destination: Cheshire, MA The Harbor House Inn ~ Bed & Breakfast

Journal Story: Had a nice breakfast at the B&B and got on the trail at 9:45. Up, up, up, towards Mount Greylock summit, the highest peak in Massachusetts! Went down and then up to Mt.Williams. Hiked into North Adams with a sore hamstring.Â  Treating it tonight.Â  Hopefully it will be better in the morning to go into Vermont.Â  Staying in Williamstown tonight!

Left Rt. 2 in North Adams and had a long gradual climb.Â  Four miles later I crossed the Massachusetts/Vermont border into Vermont which is my 9th state. Rocky trails and a lot of up and down.Â  The hills are getting higher!Â  Ended the day at Congdon Shelter 14.1 miles today.Â  Feeling a little beat up with no days off or any short days.Â  Looking for a bigger day tomorrow.

Near the endÂ  of this section.Â  25 more miles after today.Â  18.7. Planning on 20 tomorrow up and over Stratton Mountain. Today had a very steep rocky decent down to RT 9. Of course that meant going right back up on the other side of road. A long climb up a unnamed Mountain. Went across Porcupine Ridge and then climbed Little Pond Mountain at 3306 feet. Then climbed another 500 feet of elevation to Glastonbury Mountain lookout Tower . I climbed it . It was worth the climb . Spectacular 360 view. Finished the day hiking to Kid GoreÂ  Shelter. Got there at 6:10.

Got up at 4:45 todayÂ  to be on the trail by 6:00. Had a big mile day in front of me 20.5 including going up an over Stratton Mountain. I didnâ€™t know what that would bring. Vermont has been mud, rocks, roots and some great views. A lot of rock scrambled early. A nice cardio burn. Went swimming unintentionally when I was about to filter some water. Feet slipped out and landed on my rear and got shorts and part on my shirt wet.it was a soft landing so no harm done! Got a surprise Stratton MT was an easy climb. Then went up the fire tower.Â  Spectacular 360 degrees view took so pictures and headed down. Friendly trails to shelter got there around 5:15. Good 20.5 mile day!

On June 16th I hiked the 20 mile day I was hoping for. A little tough early then had to go up Stratton Mountain, surprisingly not to tough. Climbed the Fire Tower, Ran in to Lavera who Iâ€™ve seen at the Â last 2 shelters. Sheâ€™s from Oregon on a leave of absence from work. Sheâ€™s flip flopping . She started in Harpers Ferry and is hiking to Katahdin then sheâ€™ll finish the south. Sheâ€™s hoping to end up at the same shelter tonight which would be her first 20 mile day. Got to the Â summit at noon. The afternoon was relatively easy but still had to hike 9 miles. Got to shelter around 5 but made mistake of not getting water before. It was probably another mile on my day getting water! Â Iâ€™m basicly out of food except for a few candy bars to get me out the 6 miles I have in the morning. So Lavera gave me 2 Ramen noodles for supper. I always am trying to plan food close, itâ€™s less weight to carry. I could have made it on candy and cliff bars but the Ramen noodles were good. In the morning I hiked out by 9:15 and Chris Casella was picking me up by 10:00. Very happy with this section, 360 miles in 21 days and a wake up ( the term we use for a few miles in the morning) Completed fromPA/NJ border to about 50 miles into Vermont. The Vermont border was my goal, Manchester was my stretch goal. My total mileage is now 915 miles. Taking a short break for family time , Iâ€™ll be back in Manchester Vermont on July 6 heading north again. The White Mountains are looming ahead but have some hard hiking in Vermont first.

Iâ€™m on the trail again . I got picked up by Wayne Richardson at 7:15 this morning and was on the trail at 9:15 in Manchester Vermont. Planned on a 10 mile day to start my day back on the trail. Rain and mist early gave way to Â a sunny day later . The trails were wet and muddy from the rain. Climbed Mt. Bromley early . Ran into French Toast who I met in the south and later ran into Masters from Augusta, Georgia who I met in early April Â down south. Got to shelter before 3:00 lots of hikers passing thru later . Cool tonight.

Left Peru Shelter at 7:15 . The hiking got harder today. Lots of rocks and roots. I had 1 steep climb on ledge and got some beautiful views of the valley. Hiked past 2 remote lakes, some of the hikers were swimming. I stopped for lunch, and Â the afternoon brought steep rocky decents. I was glad to get to shelter at 4:30 .

On July 9 th I summited Killington Mountain in Vermont and later in the day got to Route 4 in Vermont. They say if you get off the trail too long you wonâ€™t come back. After 20 days off for a trip out west , home was pulling me away from the trail. After owning a business for almost 40 years with little time off in the summer I decided I wanted to be home more than I want to hike at this point. Iâ€™ve accomplished a lot hiking and backpacking for 970 miles on the Appalachian Trail and really not very experienced to start. I learned how to be self sufficient on the trail. It involves a lot of day by day planning on the fly; where am I getting to tonight,how much food do I have when do I stay in a town to shower and wash the only set of clothes I have, which Iâ€™m wearing. And of course hiking 12 to 23 miles a day carrying 25lbs to 30 lbs. in my pack. What an experience not to mention meeting people from all walks of life. Americans, people from overseas you name it. I would be remiss not to mention the great support and encouragement from family and friends and all the people who followed me on trail journal.com . The encouragement from everyone kept me going many days. Many people hike the AT in sections over a period of years with some others take a few years. I may be back on the trail to hike some sections next spring, Weâ€™ll see itâ€™s a long ways away. For now Iâ€™m excited to start a new chapter of my life retirement! Iâ€™ll try to do some things that work always got in the way of. Thanks again to everyone for all the positive thoughts and energy.Â Lastly I want to thank all the people that gave me rides and picked me up from the airport going to and from the trail. Iâ€™ll never forget their kindness on helping me on my journey. And at the top of the list is Jeff an Thom who helped me learn about hiking and backpacking and all the hundreds of hours spent hiking together.RP

After a long layoff in July my hiking partner Jeff/ Mule suggested since he was home nursing an injury that we should try to finish the Northern part of the AT together. It didnâ€™t take much convincing. My brother Sean and his two boys Seamus and Rohan dropped me off in Killington on August 4 th to meet Jeff and we hiked thru that terrible humid spell with heat indexes at 100. The weather people were saying to stay inside in air conditioning and we were hiking 12-15 miles . We hydrated often took breaks and made it happen. 7 days later weâ€™re at Glencliff N.H. Iâ€™ve added another 90.3 miles to my total , going over the 1000 mark 4 days ago. Tomorrow first thing itâ€™s Mt Moosilauke at 4800 feet first thing. Exciting!

We started into the White mountains at 6:30 this morning with Mt Moosilauke at 4802 in front of us. It was a steep rocky ascent but went well.Â  We summited by 10:15. Spectacular views in an out because we were above the clouds. Saw NashVegus and BiBop who were slack packing south at the top. Had a long difficult decent, steep wet ledge had to be very careful. A few slips but no falls!Â  Pushed on late in the day to take off some miles for tomorrowâ€™s planned destination. Got tents set up around 6:00 and it started raining so just in time. Tomorrow heading to Lonesome Lake Hut an AMC operated hut.Â  Looking forward to it!
Destination: Tomorrow we will make it to an AMC operated hut.

Journal Story: Camped on the Gordon Pond Trail last nite and had a lot of rain.Â  Had a hard climb right away up Mt. Wolf at 3478 feet, then hiked to South Kinsman Mt. The toughest climb yet!Â  It was hand over hand straight up.Â  Took a long time to get up, then we headed to North Kinsman, out 3rd 4000 peak.Â  We had a long decent to Lonesome Lake Hut where we stayed.

We stayed at Lonesome Lake Hut last night and had a wonderful breakfast.Â  We hit the trail around 7:45 and hiked down through Franconia Notch. Then we had a long steep climb up Little Haystack at 4900 feet, we were now on the Franconina Ridge.Â  Followed that with Mt. Lincoln andÂ  then at 5300 Mt. Lafayette.Â  We had a long decent and finished with a steep climb of Mt. Garfield, out 4th 4000 peak. Stayed at the Garfield Shelter.Â  There were 50-60 people there because it was the weekend.

Iâ€™ll be starting AT at mile 555 where I got off last year. Iâ€™ll be trying to get to Pa./NJ border where I skipped to last year. Iâ€™ve completed from Pa./NJ border thru the White mountains. Looking forward to getting down there March 21st.
